CFC's are commonly known as "chlorofluorocarbons," which are synthetic compounds composed of chlorine, fluorine, and carbon. These compounds were once widely used as refrigerants, propellants in aerosol sprays, and as solvents. However, due to their harmful effects on the ozone layer, their production and use have been largely phased out under the Montreal Protocol.

In this context, it refers to a crystal structure where the atoms are arranged in a cubic close-packed lattice with additional atoms located at the center of each face of the unit cell.
